captions.text: No notes, no script, what is this? 2008?

Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday. I really
liked your 'Keeping It Real' video, so I decided

that I am also going to try to keep it real
today, for starters by using slang that was

last popular before many of our viewers were
born. Also heads up, I got a little bit of

the tiny chicken disease, so I'm coming to
you today with my husky voice. I feel like

I could narrate a movie trailer right now
like "IN A WORLD WHERE A MAN HAS TWO CHILDREN
WHO ARE ESSENTIALLY TINY CARRIERS OF VIRUSES."

So Hank, in the last couple of months I had
this amazing trip to Ethiopia, which was so

wonderful, I'm so grateful for the opportunity
to have gone there. And then I got meningitis

which, like, less grateful for. But anyway
at some point in the last 6 months I started
to kind of have a existential crisis.

Like, Hank, young people often ask me what
they should do with their lives and I always

say that's is a question wrongly put, because
you don't just do one thing with your life.

But that's kind of a cop out because the honest
answer is I don't know what to do with my

own life, let alone what you should do with
yours! Like, we are here on Earth for a very

brief period of time, and we have to use that
time wisely, and I feel - oh God, it's coming

again. [coughs] I meant both the cough and
the existential crisis. So yeah, I don't know.

Here's what I do know: I like writing books,
and I like making stuff for, and with, Nerdfighters.

Like the experience of 'The Fault in Our Stars'
movie was awesome, Hank, but it was mostly

awesome because it felt like Hollywood was
making like a $15 million present for Nerdfighteria.

And I think it's going to be the same way
with the 'Paper Towns' movie, or even more

so, but I'm really not that into Hollywood-y
stuff; I just don't know what I should be

doing. Should I write a new book? I'm trying
to write a new book.

Should I spend tremendous amounts of time
ruminating about the terrible things that

people say about me and my work on the internet?
Probably not, but I do.

Should I be focused on MentalFloss, or Crash
Course, or the Art Assignment, or Vlogbrothers,

or the all-important AFC Wimbledon Wimbly
Wombly's? And in trying to do all of these
things, am I doing none of them well?

Now Hank, as you pointed out in your video,
these are problems of extreme, extreme privilege,

and I am grateful to have them, but I want
to figure out how to be a good Nerdfighter

and how to be part of a strong Nerdfighter
community.

And before I get to your survey -- which,
thank you for doing that survey -- in many

ways, the community is incredibly strong,
like, we just raised $300,000 for Water.org

in Ethiopia. That's more money than was raised
by the first six Projects for Awesomes combined!

So, I don't want to be all doom and gloom
about this; I just want to be honest about

the fact that, like, I am stressed out right
now and don't know what to do. Like, Hank,

it speaks to my current overall emotional
well-being that when I saw the results of

the survey about what Nerdfighters want us
to do, and the first thing that they chose

was to spend more time with our friends and
family, I began to weep. Because I know I

should spend more time with my children, I
mean, how else am I going to get all of these

viruses except from them? After friends and
family, you guys wanted us to help people

understand current events which is something
that we haven't been doing enough of lately,

Hank, because it takes a lot of work and we
are doing a lot of other things. But that

is good to know that that is a priority for
the community. Then you want us to raise money

and attention for charities around the world.That
is a hugely important part of our work, becoming

a more important part, I think, so maybe we're
good there. Then: Crash Course which we spend

a lot of time on, so: good. By the way, in
the coming months you might be seeing less

of my face on Crash Course, but I will still
be working a lot on it. But my favorite result

of this survey is that in dead-last is 'Making
viral videos that get lots of views'. So the

thing that, like, metrics and business strategies
would tell you to do is literally the least

interesting thing to Nerdfighteria. Which
is good, because it is also not that interesting

to me. You also wanted us to do more stuff
like make more Vlogbrothers videos and focus

on science education. Which is great, because
it means that your values and our values still

line up. I do have one question, though. I'm
not gonna set up a survey or anything because

I don't know how to do that, but, like, what
would you like us to do less of? So I can

write a book, and hopefully have more time
to, like, be a Nerdfighter and try to build
Nerdfightastic stuff within the community.

Nerdfighteria, thank you again for helping
to raise more than $300,000 for Water.org,

which is going to permanently transform the
lives of more than 10,000 people in Ethiopia.

And most of all, thank you for sticking with
us and helping us again and again and again
to find our way.
Hank, I will see you on Friday.

comments.text:
This video kind of blew my mind. It reminded me that my perspective on my 
own existential crisis is what's important. I spend time worrying what to 
do with my time, but that does come from an extremely privileged life. I 
may not be a millionaire but I have the privilege to spend my time as I 
please and attempt to better my life, which is not always an option for 
everyone. Thanks for the perspective John!﻿

comments.text:

how amazing you and Hank Green are I find myself just wanting to listen to 
the two of you speak. Could it be that I think listening to intelligence 
will somehow motivate me? Maybe. But thank you to the both of you for 
giving me a mental stimulant at this late hour with the hours ticking by.﻿

comments.text:
You should worry less about making a difference and trying to make things 
perfect. Dear John, you have done so much! You HAVE given back, time and 
time again. You give back so much that you spread yourself thin. You have 
created an incredible community fully of individuals that permanently 
changed the lives of 10K Ethiopians, raised awareness for hundreds of 
causes, literally saved each other's lives time and time again, and sooo 
much more. Don't just be proud of us--be proud of yourself, too. Of course, 
always strive to be your best self and improve. But don't sell yourself so 
short. Anxiety sucks, but you can't let it control you. It's okay to take a 
break sometimes and let your mind, body, heart, and soul heal and spend 
time with your friends and family. We'll still always love you. :)﻿

all of your time. Spending time with family and friends is most important 
because only you can do that. Rather than trying to help Nerdfighteria stay 
informed about current events, science, history, art, and everything else, 
perhaps find other people who will be able to take your ideas and run with 
them.﻿

I'd like to point out is basically one part of what a church is supposed to 
do. People in churches also tend to worship a god. That said, I think you 
should start reading up on ways churches have become corrupt because 
eventually, and I know this is sad, you will get old and die. And then the 
Foundation to Reduce World Suck is going to have to be run by somebody 
else. I've grown up in a community where the major nonprofit that also 
happens to economically rule the town (it's a college, so that's how it 
makes sense) has gone from caring about the environment because that saves 
money to fertilizing the lawns so much that you can smell the spray-on 
oil-based chemicals. They also do things like name buildings after people, 
which is directly opposed to what the first president of the college 
wanted. I think you should think about the long term future. Because when 
you can't control where the Foundation's money is going, somebody else 
might just spend it on advertising.﻿

comments.text:
As a high school librarian (which you, in part, helped convince me to be 
after I graduated high school back in 2007), I say focusing on writing 
should definitely be one of the priorities (as long as you still love it, 
and when you have time after family, etc.). My students, many of whom know 
nothing about the videos, love your books and your writing, and that 
matters, especially now. They give other YA books a chance because yours 
are so awesome. I fell in love with Looking for Alaska right when I was 
starting undergrad, and it's amazing to see that same thing happening with 
others. With that said, the Vlogbrothers videos are equally as important 
and in a very real way, as you guys inspire me to want to be better in 
every aspect of my life. Thanks for that, and for still being awesome.

Everything else is just gravy. And you should take breaks. Lots of them 
when needed. :-)﻿

comments.text:
Hello Mr. John Green!
Speaking to you from halfway across the world in a small area in the Middle 
East is me: an 18 year old Palestinian female high school graduate. I live 
in Palestine and go to one of the very few English-speaking schools in the 
West Bank. I came across your books a few years ago, and since then have 
been spreading the word to my fellow Arabs. We now have a small community 
of your fans who proudly identify as nerdfighters.
As you know, we live under occupation, which seldom gives us any 
opportunity for economical, emotional, physical, educational, and mental 
growth. We are limited. We are denied basic human rights.
Despite this, someone opened the first legit movie theater in Palestine 
less than a month ago. Just in time for TFiOS. I was ecstatic, and I loved 
the movie (although I liked the book more and was pissed off that some 
little things were left out like the fact that we didn’t hear Augustus’ 
parents fighting with him, or the fact that Augustus and Hazel had their 
date by a stream not a restaurant! .. although the restaurant was very 
beautiful I must say).
John, a lot of violence has been happening in this part of the world. 
Innocent children are being murdered, and no one is being held responsible. 
Hundreds of Palestinians, young and old, are in Israeli prisons under 
“administrative detention”. The Israeli soldiers came into my town just the 
other week and burst into a house and basically flipped it upside down and 
left. Yesterday morning a 15 year old boy was taken by an Israeli settler 
and was beaten and burned to death. Yesterday night, a young girl was a 
victim of an intended hit and run and is currently being hospitalized. 
There is rumor of 3 Jewish boys being kidnapped and murdered by 
Palestinians in Hebron, but we haven’t seen pictures of their identified 
bodies. All of the stories that I mentioned earlier can be backed up with 
pictures all found on the internet.
I know you are an advocate of helping people with cancer, but I was hoping 
you could also be an advocate of social justice.
I don’t want you to feel burdened with all of this, but I was just 
wondering if you could make a vlog about this situation and mention 
Palestinians. If you could even do a little shout out to your Palestinian 
nerdfighters that would be amazing. We really love you John, and Hank too! 
Thank you for sharing your talent with us.
I guess I’ll end with this: In a seemingly hopeless situation, they 
fashioned within their souls a creative optimism that strengthened them. 
Their bottomless vitality transformed the darkness of frustration into the 
light of hope.
That was from Martin Luther King’s “Strength to Love” which I’m currently 
reading. And again John, thanks for being a little light of hope.
I really hope I don’t sound cheesy,
Fellow nerdfighter, 
Rachel

I commented that message in early July on one of your websites, and I guess 
you don't check that website. When I saw this vlog, it reminded me of the 
message and I decided to find it and post it again. Hoping to hear from you 
this time. ﻿

sound like you're superhuman when to me, you seem like a normal guy who 
just makes a really big effort to do good things, which is like the best 
thing you can do.  ﻿

there were so many awesome options)! Me, personally I'm not so much 
interested in video games which is why I would say do it less... I 
absolutely love the web series Hank produces, but in my opinion you could 
take it a little more slow pace there and would not have to have different 
projects overlapping. I love the crashcourse rhythm with 2 videos a week

little less frequency with Scishow, considering that you still have SciShow 
space to add up, would not be a desaster either.
Oh and John I love to see your face on Mental Floss, but all the subs are 
doing a fantastic job as well - so I guess it was a great choice to bring 
in more hosts. I would love for you to have more time so that you can get 
inspired, work on new story ideas and get back to normal after the TFIOS 
extravaganza (although it might start all over again with the Paer Towns 
movie).
And yeah on the life crisis, I have to jump from university life into a 
grown up job pretty soon, if I find one, because I'm about to graduate with

so I feel you on that and won't stress you with the question what to do 
now.﻿

Like many here, what I would like you to do less of is worry and work and 
exhaust yourself.  We'll miss you, of course, if you step back your visible 
roles or take a sabbatical, but that's ok!  Let the community relieve you 
for a while, please.  Definitely do less obsessing over internet 
negativity, please, but otherwise, keep with what brings you the most joy 
and let go of what brings you less.  Or step back from *everything* for a 
while and see how you're feeling.

I mean, seriously, I have two small plague bearers and existential 
uncertainty myself and it's exhausting even without trying to spin the many 
plates of Nerdfighteria to boot.  You're not a superhero*--get some rest!


*Note to Henry and Alice: your father absolutely is a superhero, don't be 
fooled.  We just need to get him to take off the cape and take care of 
himself for a while.  Can you hide the cape?  Maybe arrange to throw up on 
it?  I know we're talking about a metaphorical cape here, but I have faith 
that this will be no impediment to your germ warfare prowess.  Godspeed, 
small humans.  A grateful Nerdfighteria thanks you.﻿

expand on it though and that is a good role for a distributor. They should

artist does not have.

You said people saying "bad stuff" about you on the internet was stressing 
you out? Well, know that all that means is you still have things to learn, 
and that in itself is a great thing. That's why artists keep drawing and 
writers keep writing, right? That's why I do at least. The more you do it, 
the better you get. The better you get, the more attention you get, the 
more comments you get. That means bad comments sometimes, or at least some 
harsh critique, but take what they say and think about it. Is it REALLY 
true? If so, prove them wrong. Fix it in the next thing you write. You said 
it yourself: "A book is an imperfect thing written by an imperfect person" 
(I really hope I'm quoting that correctly... my memory isn't wonderful, but 
the point stands.) Of course every book will get critique, but I'd bet that 
instinct people have to "troll" is because there's no way to improve when 
all someone gets is praise.
And if that doesn't work, there's thousands if not millions of great 
comments and reviews you could find out there.﻿

comments.text:
I think that as humans we put emphasis on doing things because we "feel 
like it," or because we "want to do it," but I think sometimes those 
feelings should only be one factor in making decisions, and most certainly 
not the primary factor, at least in most cases. I think that "wants" and 
"feelings" are simple impulses that are easy to determine and don't 
represent the reasoning potential of a human, whereas thinking through what 
one should do, and what makes sense for one to do, is the true strength of 
humans. It is why, I believe, humans are the dominant species on this 
planet, but our strength is only present as long as we give more weight to 
our thoughts, and less to our impulses. Of course, I don't believe that we 
should ignore impulses entirely; we're not machines, but I think that all 
decisions besides the most basic day-to-day choices should be decided upon 
through thought and analysis of what affects the decision, and analysis of 
how are impulses are affecting our own decision making. I think if we just 
use our strength of reason, we can benefit both ourselves and the world 
with it. ﻿

I noticed that Nerdfighteria's well-meaning replies sometimes contrast with 
what you already know you want—e.g. the suggestion of a sabbatical vs. Hank 
saying that he enjoys making Vlogbrothers/Games with Hank videos. Maybe we 
Nerdfighters need a little more detail about what each project means to you 
and how much time you spend on it in order to give more meaningful advice. 
This could be in the form of just a quick document or list or something, 
just to give us more context. After all, context is everything.

Regardless, DFTBA from a (similarly stressed) college-applicant Nerdfighter 
- I can relate, at least to some extent.

PS. To answer the original question, I'd suggest doing less of something 
I'm prone to a lot: thinking too much about the future and not focusing on 
the present moment. Even taking a five minute break or a walk or something 
to refocus on the present helps me alleviate the (admittedly imaginary) 
looming demons of the future.﻿

comments.author: Jake Vlogs

comments.text:
A few things:

1) As always, a vehement appreciation of this community. This channel can 
be defined as entertainment, but what a person desires out of entertainment 
obviously differs from person to person and this channel is unequivocally 
meaningful, thought-provoking entertainment that can help ease our seeming 
plight of being human. The comments are literally doing that. So, yeah, 
stuff accomplished right there.

2) What other people said: Please worry less!! I know you want to 
accomplish everything to the best of your ability and to the best of 
humanity's benefit, but you also need to care for yourself and worrying 
about things is not beneficial. Take the time you need to feel focused 
about projects that make you the most energetic, and the least overwhelmed 
(And also obviously that are doing good things, but that's literally all of 
nerdfighteria's projects, so that won't be hard to find).

3) Maybe you guys should discuss one of you taking a break, or at least, 
deviating from the normal schedule to alleviate some of the aforementioned 
stress & worry. I personally would love to see other people on the channel, 
more things of you guys just talking (unscripted), etc. Maybe during that 
time, John could focus on his book, and being a Dad, and as Hank said 
somewhereV, Vbros videos make him happy and energetic which is fabulous. 
Everyone wins.

4) Another disclaimer: Anything you choose to do is trying to help other 
people, so at this point, again, it's whatever makes you guys happy and 
least stressed.﻿

comments.author: Anh Uong

comments.text:
Dear Hank, John, and all of Nerdfighteria,
Let me say why you guys are awesome. Besides the fascinating, informative, 
and entertaining videos I would like to note the difference in the 
comments. When you read a comment's section on YouTube you often pull away 
feeling like a waste of space and your faith in human severely damaged. 
People are always complaining, or accusing, or being vulgar for no sensible 
reason (if there is a sensible reason.) Even if the video is about being 
aware of the problems in a culture there is still a negative aspect. But 
then I look at vlogbrother comments and I see people who are supportive and 
I don't feel so awful anymore. To people who say "YouTube comments are 
offensive. Get used to it" we shouldn't be used to it. We have to hold 
ourselves at higher standard. Once in a while we see a not-so-awesome-post. 
But that's only once in a while. So thank you Hank, John, and Nerdfighteria 
for being as awesome as you are.﻿

do less of. There will be days when you write a book; days when you want to

vlogs. The nerdfighters can't make you guys do anything for a long period 
of time. Life is about balance and so it's normal to feel lost once in a 
while. The point is, do what you guys want to. Please don't feel like the 
nerdfighters will disapprove of any of your actions because we support you 
2 very much. ﻿

John and Hank,
I haven't been a Nerdfighter for all that long, but everything I have 
experienced related to it has been amazing. I have seen and gotten involved 
with so little of it so far, and yet I am amazed at how loving and 
accepting this community is and how much you guys put into it/us. You guys 
absolutely deserve a break. Also as an idea to keep stress to a minimum, if 
you have been super busy or you just tired or worn out or stressed, either 
do an unedited vlog-y video from your phone for that week, or do it another 
day. I know that your thing is "Good Morning Hank/John, it's 
Tuesday/Friday," and it's good to have a schedule, but life gets crazy and 
it doesn't really matter all that much.
Thanks for everything guys!
-Rachel﻿

comments.text:
This is going to sound negative but I mean it in the most positive way 
possible.

Stop broadcasting your celebrity.

It is great that you've been so successful but I think most Nerdfighters 
would agree that we like John and Hank the nerds (read real people). Every 
time I see you on the set of a movie, in front of a crowd of thousands, 
talking to well-known people (even Bill Gates) it makes it harder to see 
you as person. You become bigger than your viewers and detachment and 
resentment start to set in. If you never again mention that you're making a 
movie, or selling books, or that people are asking your advice on being 
successful that would be great. We could go back to thinking you're just 
another dude with a camera.

If you want to maintain your individuality and stay connected with the 
community you have to put the celebrity dampeners on full. There are forces 
out there who want to brand and sell you. Resist that or you and this 
community will become a sold-out shell for someone else's profit.

We can do great things together. You are focal point of our DFTBA energy so 
direct it out into the world not back at us.﻿

comments.text:
Dearest John,
I probably don't have to remind you that you are doing great. You have a 
very broad interest, and very good intentions and that speaks for you. It 
is understandable that there are simply so many opportunities to change 
things that touch you so deeply that it is hard to say no. Also, doing only 
one thing will probably not help you because people simply want to do the 
best they can. But what makes you most happy? What makes you feel you? 
Ofcourse, family and writing are important. By spending time with your 
family, people who accept you and keep you with both feet on the ground 
will ensure that you have a good sense of who you are. Writing seems like 
being your main passion: by writing you can both strive for nerdfighter 
goals, and creatively express yourself. Don't be to hard on yourself! My 
main advise: go have a walk, go take a total break, for as long as you need 
to. Or go for a walk everyday, which gives you the time to think about 
life, or just not think at all. You don't have to perform perfectly in this 
life. What is perfect anyways. Yes, you can influence the lives of others a 
bit, please do so, but you are not responsible for all that is wrong.

You have probably guessed that this is what I tell myself when having 
existencial questions, but I can tell you, they will fade away if you give 
yourself some rest, and your subconcience will help you with it. Also, you 
are not alone ;)

Love,
Jessie﻿

comments.text:
I'm not an author, but I spend most of my free time writing, and I'm trying 
hard to balance between my studies, my writing, my family and friends, my 
health, doing the things I love, doing the things I have to do, and just 
spend time alone. When I think about it, what do I end up doing? Nothing. 
And yes, I'm aware of the fact that your life is probably much much more 
complicated than mine is, but the thing is, when we spend time thinking, we 
end up not doing. If you woke up in the morning feeling like writing your 
book, but then you started to think 'oh no, I can't! I won't have time to 
do this and that' you'll eventually spend an hour thinking and trying to 
balance rather than an hour of actually writing and enjoying. We should 
balance our priorities, and what goes on top of the list is family and 
religion. Then comes your own pleasure, doing the things you really really 
love doing. Next up comes the things that determines your future, like your 
job or in my case, my studies. Then comes other people's enjoyment, which 
is the things you do for us like vlogbrothers videos etcetera. While you 
can't balance all these in one day, you can balance them in a week. When 
you think about it, if you spend every weekend with your family, and taking 
your kids to hang out, then you'll find yourself cancelling everything that 
comes in a weekend just so that you can the simple pleasure of making those 
you love the most and yourself happy. It's all about moderation, doing the 
things you should do, doing the things you love to do, and doing the things 
you have to do. If you balance all three, you'll find yourself complete. 
But that's coming from a 15 years old, I'm not really experienced so 
yeah...﻿

I'm with all the other commenters who have suggested John in particular 
take a break. There has been so much going on recently and he has handled 
it all with extreme grace and fortitude. Now, I think we would all like to 
see him get some rest and take some time to be with his family and friends.

On a more personal note, I totally understand your frustration trying to 
write something with so much pressure. I had a project recently that 
everyone I knew wanted me to finish and asked me about constantly. It was 
supposed to be my dream, but the way I was going about it was wrong. I got 
so caught up trying to please everyone else that I began hating my work. It 
took me scrapping the whole thing, disappointing everyone, and starting 
over to start to get things back in order. 

Creative work is hard. Never let anyone make you feel less than for 
choosing to do it in your own time and in your own way. :)﻿

This may be a bit of a stretch, but I think that perhaps one the greatest 
projects that Nerdfighteria could take on is the creation of the 
film-adaptation of Looking For Alaska. This may sound absurd from first 
glance, but think about it. As a young filmmaker myself, I know that 
filmmaking and acting talent is not only found in Hollywood--the amount of 
amazing filmmakers and creators here on YouTube and those in Nerdfighteria 
willing to create such a project is a lot more significant than one may 
initially expect. And they're talented--it doesn't take a degree in film to 
create something that pleases thousands of people. It would be a film by 
Nerdfighteria for Nerdfighteria, with the crew consisting primarily of 
Nerdfighters who aspire to create but may never get the chance otherwise. 
It would be the ultimate Nerdfighter experience and create a greater sense 
of community than ever before. Just a thought, of course.﻿

comments.text:
It seems odd to put the question that way: "What should we do more/less 
of?" I think it combines two different issues in a way that's bound to get 
them confused. The first issue is what do nerdfighters like or like less 
about what the vlogbrothers do. The second issue is what should John and/or 
Hank do or not do, and that can only be answered by John and Hank. And in 
my opinion, given that you guys have the privilege of doing as much or as 
little of what you want to do, you should probably make those decisions 
based on your mission in life -- your values, calling, sense of identity. 
(Richard Bolles wrote some really interesting things about finding one's 
mission.) It seems as if that should mean a willingness to give up doing a 
lot of really good things in order to do the few things that are most 
important. What nerdfighters like or don't like is surely only a tiny 
ingredient in the decision-making process.

For what it's worth, to me John's identity is "YA novelist who posts really 
interesting vlogs on youtube." All the rest is gravy. I like the quiet, 
contemplative, thoughtful John even more than the swirling, hyperactive 
bundle of energy that is the usual vlogbrother John. I still think your 
silent video was your best video; there's more power in silence than in 
words.

But what do I know?﻿

comments.text:
You guys have so many different channels and projects Just trying to name

you've started the projects, it might be good to delegate other people to 
run them for you. For example, get someone to host/edit mental floss or 
crash course or sci show for you. Whichever channel you enjoy the least, 
let someone else run it. You could still make guest appearances or help 
come up with content, but not have the stress of shooting and producing it. 
We all want you guys to stop worrying and stressing and be able to actually 
enjoy all that you've done. Sometimes it's good to take a break from 
looking forward and admire where you've been. The nerfighteria community 
will support whatever decisions you make and buy any book you write. We'd 
even buy your grocery lists.﻿

not doing anything and its a visiouce cycle and you feel like there's no 
escape and then THE PEOPLE come and THEY help you and THEY need caps lock 
be cause THEY are just that amazing and a couple days ago what I was sure 
was the worst day of my life very quickly became one of the best and a 
whole lot of bad things were made okay and a whole lot of good things

Sorry for the rant.﻿

comments.text:
The comments on this one warm my heart as they are sweet and loving toward 
our adoptive family members of the Greens - Both Hank and John are 
fantastic inspirations of so much creation, passion, and awesomeness that 
it is easy to forget that they are human beings that need down time and 
rest (Often when I have nothing left to go on I will re-watch a vlogbrother 
video to convince me to get back to the myriad of tasks because I can't let 
my students down.  In that same concept - there is a point when you can't 
push on and must rest (or your body betrays you and makes you rest).  I am 
in favor of some sort of planned breaks & of all of the projects - the 
one's I don't even watch are the gaming one's because like some of the 
other commenters I am a part of the older demographic of nerdfighteria and 
the gaming videos are less of a draw for me.  I do enjoy many of the stream 
of thought or thoughts from places - but ultimately the best part of the 
vlogbrothers is that it exists.  The fact that they are a little present 
waiting in my video subscriptions or popping up on my news feed just makes 
a hectic schedule suddenly less pressing and reminds me why I am grading a 
mountain of essays/projects/tests. ﻿

Hey John, I'm actually doing a presentation on you for my graduate level 
business leadership class. I will be discussing how you are one of the few 
examples today of "authentic leadership" as proposed by Luthans & Avolio 
(2003). This discussion of what we should do less of comes up a lot in 
graduate school and I would recommend a book called 7 habits of highly 
effective people by Stephen Covey. Essentially, what it says is that what 
you do less of should be determined by you and your values and not by us. ﻿

After reading through a bunch of the comments, I think the overwhelming 
majority of us want you to rest, John and Hank. Delegating seems like it 
might be a good solution, especially with the educational videos. But 
several Nerdfighters mentioned that there might be "seasons" of the shows 
that you're involved in. In the summer, perhaps, John does a season of 
Crash Course and Hank does a season of Sci Show, and then we have an off 
season, which could be without content or with a different host, or 
multiple host, whatever works best. 

But, like so many people have said, we want you to be rested and happy more 
than anything else in the world. We love and support you so much. Thank you 
for all that you do, but you don't need to do so much :)﻿

comments.text:
+John Green I think your question came from an incorrect premise. The 
question isn't what we want less of, it's what we'd be okay with seeing 
less of. There are segments of Nerdfighteria in love with each aspect of 
what you guys do. It's a matter of, "If X went away or was not focused on, 
how much would you miss it?" The difficult part is knowing that there are 
people who love the things that I'm not particularly attracted to. For 
example, I am not an avid watcher of Sci Show or the sciencey half of Crash 
Course, but I know it's beneficial and there are plenty of Nerdfighters who 
enjoy them. If I had to choose, I'd say someone else take over for you on 
Mental Floss and others take over for Hank on Sci Show (which I know has 
frequent guest hosts already). Rosianna would make a fantastic Mental Floss 
host, by the way. A British accent always makes things sound classy.﻿

comments.text:
+Alice alicee  Remember that where you are now is giving you a good solid 
basic education, you can focus more on what interests you specifically at 
uni.  At 17 - you don't need to know what you are going to do with your 
life yet, you have all the time for that later - you can even change your 
mind in uni!  Focus on your coursework presentation and your exams to pass 
and not have to repeat year 12.  Worry about the rest after you pass.  And 
if you have to do year 12 over - that means you know what to expect for the 
exams and can be prepared next time.  Either way it can be a win for you 
where you are now, even though it doesn't *feel* like that at all.  It's ok 
to be worried and unsure, but don't let that keep you from focusing on what 
is right in front of you and important right now - getting through the 
exams.  I promise, it's not wasting your life. No one can take knowledge 
away from you, take all they will give you and try to focus on the closest 
goal - passing.  I believe in you! DFTBA!

comments.text:
Nerdfighters, it seems like in every video for the past month or so, John 
and Hank (mostly John. Hank is a never-diminishing force of energy, John is 
but less so, we of course love him anyways) have been thanking us profusely 
for our contributions to these incredible charities. That's all well and 
good, but John is a father. Look at the bags under his eyes! This father of 
Nerdfighteria needs a break. I propose a sabbatical for him to focus on his 
book and his family. How many of you guys are writers? I am. Focusing on 
too many projects that distract from a novel feels good at first, but when 
you get used to it, the nourishment you get from writing seems harder and 
harder to come by. I don't want us to take that from John.
With the community he's helped create, we'd be OK without him for a few 
weeks. He needs a real vacation.
Guys, what do you think? Am I reading too much into it? And if I'm right, 
how do we tell him? ﻿

comments.text:
I say this in the most affectionate way possible: I think it would be 
awesome for y'all to stop taking "public vacations" with your smartphones 
on you all the time.

For instance, I knew in advance that John was going to go to a cabin in 
Tennessee post-TFiOS movie, and that sounds stalker-ish, except I read 
about it in, like, New York Times Magazine. I am no luddite (I make my 
living through YouTube videos, for gosh sakes), and I'm grateful that y'all 
have been so open with us over the years, but I think there is much to be 
said for truly "unplugging" once in a while. I got this idea from Gwen 
Bell's blogs on "digital sabbaticals" and also a TED Talk called "Quarterly 
Week off the Grid." Undertaking my own Internet-less periods or vacations 
(by literally giving my wife my phone and telling her to hide it from me 
for X number of days) has helped keep me from burning out despite a fairly 
large workload. And as workloads go, I imagine that mine is only a fraction 
of yours.

If you guys even wanted to just take the occasional week away from 
Vlogbrothers (either by not having a video, or by having guest hosts), I am 
absolutely certain that we Nerdfighters would *not* respond with cries of 
"Those Greens -- those lazy GREENS! -- remember when they used to be 
awesome?"

I understand and admire that y'all have followed the "we only don't make 
videos when sick or celebrating major holidays" rules for so long. But it's 
worth noting that those rules were created at the very beginning of 
Brotherhood 2.0, when it was unimaginable that you would have to abide by 
them for the next 7 years (and also when you guys had an easier time having 
private lives, and didn't have an 
educational/merchandise/charitable/conference enterprises to guide, and 
etc. etc.).

Anyway, tl;dr: I guess what I'm saying is that I love being a Nerdfighter 
with y'all, and I want you guys to be happier, less exhausted people. Play 
with Legos, veg out with the new Smash Bros., visit a beet farm for a week 
-- whatever. But take time that is truly for your selves and families. 
You've given us all more time than we could have ever asked, and I think I 
speak for many Nerdfighters when I say that we would love to return the 
favor.

Your pal,
Mike﻿

comments.text:
Your story mirrors mine in a lot of ways, and it's not as uncommon as you 
might think. I've struggled with depression for almost a decade, ended up 
failing almost everything last year bc I just couldn't focus anymore, and 
am now on a study break so I can catch up & hopefully get into therapy (I'm 
on antidepressants now too, which have worked almost unexpectedly well for 
me, but they're not perfect). I think one thing we have to realise is that 
it's ok to take time off. It's ok to be ill and focus on trying to get 
better before trying to finish your education - your degree won't mean much 
to you if you spend all those years suffering and hating life. If you 
google "online cognitive behavioural therapy" you'll find a bunch of free 
resources that might help you cope until you can get professional help 
(I've just started looking into them myself, so I don't have anything I can 
quite recommend yet) - a lot of it is for pay, but there are some free 
resources as well - and 7cupsoftea.com seems like a good place if you need 
to talk to someone anonymously (it's another place that I've seen around, 
it's been recommended, but I haven't tried it out enough myself to really 
be able to say one way or the other. But it's worth a shot, right?). I just 
need you to know that you're not alone - far, FAR from it - and it WILL get 
better and we are here for you. It might be a bit finicky to get, but there 
IS help, and we CAN fix this. It might not feel like it right now, but it 
really is worth the fight. I had completely forgotten what life could feel 
like without a constant cloud of hopelessness tainting everything I did, to 
the point where I'm still not sure who I even AM if I'm not depressed. But 
it's a good kind of confusion, like a whole world has opened up to me that 
I didn't even know existed. It's like, I'm not even actually well, I'm just 
less ill, but some days it feels like the world has gone from a grey scale 
to technicolour, when things are good. I lost the last seven years to 
depression - a third of my life - and I know hope might not really feel 
like an option anymore, but persevere. It really will get better, I promise.

It's ok. If you are feeling suicidal you need to be focusing on your mental 
health first. You are not a failure. You are not weak. You just need a 
little help. If you can afford it at all you should look into some 
counseling. If not you could look for a support group/ go see a pastor or 
other religious leader, if that's your thing. They frequently have at least 
some training in counseling. You should probably go see a doctor and talk 
to them about whether some antidepressants are right for you.

Just hang in there. Dropping out of college isn't then end of the world. 
You can go back later if you feel you need to.
Ditto with the writing and the drawing. You are probably much better than 
you think. Get better first, and then you could ask some outside input.

comments.text:
Firstly *hugs tightly* I am so sorry that you are hurting so.
Secondly, doing things you enjoy like writing and drawing are /never/ a 
waste of time when you are on the verge of completely fracturing. I know it 
might feel like it and some people might see it as such but if that's what 
makes you happy DO IT!! And keep at it because I guarantee those will be 
the things that keep you going until you start to feel better.
If it still feels like a waste of time, use those activities as rewards for 
completing other tasks. For instance, I might use sewing as a reward for 
getting the laundry sorted and getting a load going in the washer, or 
reading or writing as a reward for finishing a homework assignment. It's a 
good way to give yourself motivation and set an achievable short term goal 
that can help you start to power through.
I would also recommend just going outside when it's sunny. Don't have to be 
active or anything just go outside, get some air and some sunshine. If you 
have it in you, take a walk around the block. Or do some yoga.
And then just let yourself relax. Deep breathing helps. Depression is a 
painful, often stressful thing to live with. Suicidal thoughts and urges 
even more so. So just taking a breather can do wonders. Spend a day 
pampering yourself with a bubble bath and spa things at home. Curl up with 
netflix and your favorite cocoa or tea. Take time to focus on your 
wellbeing. The future doesn't wait but you have time to decide how you 
wanna take it on.
I really hope at least one of these suggestions helps. <3

you asked the hardest question of all for me because what I love most is 
the variety of what you guys do. So what I really want is for you to clone 
yourselves and do more of everything without making yourselves balls of 
stress or neglecting your friends and family.

I think what you're really struggling with is balance because there's merit 
it all the things you tend to pursue and I think they really work best as a 
whole--kinda like Big History. Because we need the deep and the funny and 
the game and the education and the genuine connection. And I think what 
that balance should be is another big question, like 'what should I do with 
my life?', that's super complicated and not static, you have to find the 
balance that works for you as life throws things at you and as you change.

so I can't really answer your question all I can say is that you should 
both follow your instincts on what you feel you need to work on for your 
own mental health and fulfillment and understand that what you do-even when 
it's jokes or just rambling-is huge and important and it can change over 
time and still be the right thing.

sorry this doesn't really make things easy, but it is my vote of support 
for whatever you guys decide to do.﻿

comments.author: Lily En Pointe

comments.text:
Sounds to me like you have a similar problem a lot of creative people have 
- just too much stuff you are passionate about and want to do, and it's 
unbelievably tough to try and condense them down. I've been having that 
lately, although obviously not being a Green brother it hasn't been quite 
on the same scale haha! To be honest I've relegated certain things to 'do 
for fun' status, and other stuff to 'this is what I want to spend my energy 
on'. And in terms of writing a book, creative inspiration can't be forced, 
and you must never feel like you HAVE to write something. The frustrating 
thing with creativity is that you can sit there for hours and it won't 
come, and then on the train or in a random conversation an idea will hit 
which you literally have to scribble down right there and then, and 
suddenly it all starts coming together. 

I feel like I'm teaching you to suck eggs here, haha! But either way, good 
luck getting everything together, don't be afraid to ditch certain things 
or delegate them out to others, and most importantly don't feel obliged to 
do anything for anyone. Ultimately it's your life, family and work, so it's 
up to you how you do that. :) ﻿

concentrate your energies. I feel like you shouldn't be asking us what we 
want because we have a vested interest in keeping you close and visible as 
often as possible. We care about you guys and if that means seeing less of

accept it, and to be supportive of whatever choices you make, even if they

better quickly :)﻿
